4wUWyFEKqusc89o7-GKJNA.text: I adore this place when you first walking it has a great theme love the vibes here and I loved the spicy tonkotsu but best part about this place was our waitress she was so sweet and kind explained everything very well so if you come here ask for Ada she's wonderful !!!

jXyhSitZdMAUqfUVZnimFg.text: Very authentic taste & also setting! Love the decor inside. Very friendly & attentive staff and the food was on point. Will definitely return to try more food.

vY2A9ylViJjfOps9vsUclQ.text: As a vegetarian it's hard for me to compare this to other ramen spots. While I read that other places have better, I have to say that this place stands out because they actually have a veggie option. A veggie option with actual flavor!! It's spicy miso and not just a bland veggie broth like what most places offer (if they offer veggie at all). Also their green iced tea is great too. Staff is very attentive and everything is timely. I love it.

uAhh-a2CnhLuYIuwViz4lA.text: Friendly service, good but not great ramen, udon, and some other foods.  I would recommend Omoide if you live in the southwest.  Sometimes it is too far to go to Fukumimi on Trop and Eastern,and Omoide is solid.  The big negative is the lack of consistency in the cooks/chef's.  They take too long, harldy the same people each time I go, and for that I almost dropped it to a 3 star but the friendly service countered the slow cook times.

WRJkxgL10CvPVbUSu42lEA.text: The ambience is perfect.. Feels like the typical ramen place down Chinatown. Prices are reasonable. Tonkotsu ramen is $7.50 I think and gyoza 5pcs is $5. Good sized portions. The chashu is not as tender as monta ramen, but it's still good. Customer service is excellent! Going back next week!

QgnLYQbkVwKOWmt_Hwa7dg.text: It was an ok Japanese place. It was great but it wasn't bad either. The place is ok, the ambiance was just alright. The servers were nice and try to give you the best service ASAP. The good was ok, I ordered the Spicy Tonkatsu shoyo ramen. The flavor was right, I have tried numerous Japanese places and to compare their ramen, I would say it is average. The price is ok for what you get but I feel that charged too much for gratuity, their service was ok but I felt that they charged as too much for that and there was only 5 of us when we ate their..so that's for that.

HV9Dts3fac3rjO3bixJIQg.text: This place is great!  Reminds me of my days living in Japan as a exchange student.  Food quality and service is awesome and very fair reasonable prices!

Jfu_izu6YjhM8_47p53Wgw.text: Went here yesterday looking for a quick lunch.  Had a bowl of the chaschu miso ramen.  Wow, great miso broth, tender noodles and very succulent pieces of chaschu pork that were tender and thinly sliced.  Very spacious and nice decor.  The two waitresses were great making recommendations and checking in to make everything was ok.  Will definately be back next time Im on the west side of town.

d-GhqxgWnPToPRfxc9u_vg.text: I was excited to find out a ramen place within 5 miles from home. Woohooo... The place is spacious and clean. The decor is not too busy. I actually like the decor and ambience. 5/5 score. The staff is 5/5, although she was by herself for 10mins(exluding kitchen staff). There were about 3 groups plus us, she did well in taking orders in a timely manner.  Now for the food : ) 3/5 we had the tempura mix. Nothing fancy about that. 3.5/5 for the ramen. I had the spicy tonkutso miso. I was a little worried when i saw it. I thought it'll be super spicy. Not at all. It might be 4/10 spice level. But the ramen itself is good except for the bamboo shoot. I fished it all out. Nasty! Please use fresh ones. My hubby ordered the regular tonkutso ramen, i tried it. Just ok. He said he had better. Now for the black sesame ice cream... yum-O! 5/5!!! Now, will i ever come back? Probably. If we're too lazy to go to chinatown.

WpSiSn8qdI5eTqFwMFqZgA.text: The Buta Shio is great - the udon noodles are so springy and fresh. The gyoza are also fantastic, they do have a little bit of spicy to them.

nw8QKW0-wcrEQOzxjNyVzQ.text: I was really excited to have a ramen/udon opening up near my house. But was very dissapointed. The noodles wasnt fresh at all, it was a bit hard. my best friend and boyfriend both agreed. The udon noodles werent even udon! udon noodles are suppose to be thick noodles. Not only the noodles werent good but the broth too. Also they claim to close at 1am but in reality when you get there at 12am they tell you that they stop serving.

lWv_Lzm0h_uuNFnBoMOVAg.text: I've been to this restaurant 3 times now. First was when they just opened. I liked the decor and menu selection. We ordered 2 different ramen and zaru soba. All noodles tasted not fully cooked and broth wasn't impressive. Service was pretty good but overall, we were disappointed. Because the place is so close to my house, we wanted to like the place and gave another try. Second time we went, it was packed but had only one server. Service was friendly but slow. At least noodles tasted better. Then finally the third time we went, the restaurant now seemed all in place and settled. Service was prompt, very friendly and attentive, and noodles were perfect texture. We ordered tonkotsu, spicy tonkotsu miso, ten zaru, gyoza and pumpkin croquette (i tried potato croquette before but pumpkin croquette was more flavorful) and all tasted very good. I was satisfied with food and service. So glad they have improved since they first opened and now met our expectations! I'm definitely going back!

E5Pzu088JOk_brl8_6gCSA.text: I like coming to Omoide because it's near my house and their food is decent. But, my experience today wasn't so hot. We ordered to-go and had to wait 30 minutes for just two bowls. When we got home with our food, I wasn't pleased to find that they forgot the sauce for one of our bowls and the tonkatsu was too hard (probably fried too long) for the other bowl.

IWsJTMfatD8whTMd7OcLOg.text: We had the udon and my 5 year old cleared the bowl. Everything was authentic and it was served just as we asked for it. I had the curry udon and it was good as well.  The udon noodles were thawed and served but it was still tasty and hit the spot. The katsu curry was just as good as you will find in Japan. The spice was perfect for me but maybe a bit much for my 3yo. I'll definitely be back to try the ramen.

OPqXX3-sh6YSOy_LJ2AFpw.text: Great ramen place away from China Town. Very cute, trendy place. We were grated and seated right away. Ramen was great, not too salty, which is the best part. Same as the Chasu don, a bit sweet. We'll be back.

xcnT4hlNaacxUf6t8jGASQ.text: Went to try out this place with a friend of mine since this is a brand new restaurant from the group that owns Soyo and Oyshi in the lot.  Like both restaurants, Omoide has a plain exterior and a beautifully decorated interior.  Unlike Soyo and Oyshi tho, I think Omoide needs some work on their food.  I ordered the Karaage chicken but it was a bit dry and tough to eat.  My friend ordered their cold soba noodles.  I normally don't like soba noodles since they tend to taste funny out here in Vegas whenever I've ordered, but his was surprisingly good. If they spend their time tweaking with the menu by specializing just a little more, I think Omoide could become a gem of a restaurant like her sisters Soyo and Oyshi.

Their pan seared pork gyoza, although the portion was small, was nice and crispy and worth every penny!

0JV5LwR8t0QUaOgs4ezOHw.text: I ordered Tonkatsu w/ egg ($7.50 for the soup + $1.5 for the egg)  I have pretty high expectations for ramen places, and Omoide met those expectations!   It's a cute little restaurant, but seating size is grander than most ramen places I've been to. The soup I ordered was delicious - Tonkatsu! The soup base was creamy, had sufficient noodles & sides, but extra meat wouldn't hurt. However, overall, the entire dish was a good portion size & filling.  The only negative would be that their hot tea is $1.50 w/ free refills, where other places give this as complimentary.  However, despite this, I'd still come back here to try their other ramen flavors & curry bowls.

I had low expectations but even those were not met. I ordered the ten don and my friend got the chashu bowl.  The food came out very quickly, almost too quickly, like it was just sitting there. My friend and I were both disappointed by the small portions. I didn't enjoy anything in my bowl. The tempura was soggy and unappetizing and the rice was gummy. My friend was unimpressed with her meal as well.  Once we finished eating we both mentioned how we still felt a little hungry but didn't have any desire to order more food. She even discussed what she planned on reheating from her previous night's leftovers that she had at home...   I don't have any desire to return to Omoide.

Not to mention not even water was served until she came to take our order. The food came out pretty quickly. Liked the atmosphere but the service kind of sucks....

ojY7gYFO4-KF7UrfU27TSg.text: Omoide is a very good restaurant with a lot of options, which I can't tell is a good thing or a bad thing. I found myself looking at the menu for around 10 minutes because everything looked so good and I wasn't sure what to choose! I'm sure it is a good thing though because it keeps you wanting to come back for more! The atmosphere was nice and the decorations were very intricate. They also had a very generous time allotted for their happy hour (9pm-1am, BOGO drinks). The food also did not disappoint at all. My girlfriend and I had a beef onigiri (sorry it's not pictured, we were too hungry!) and an order of takoyaki to start. For our dishes, I got the tonkotsu curry don and my girlfriend got the spicy tonkotsu ramen, which were both very good. The curry don was probably the best curry I've had at a place that doesn't specialize in curry. The ramen didn't have a strong tasting broth but it was still good! 10/10 would come back here to try the rest of the menu!

cdtxPAVBc0fWbAmGmB7Psg.text: On the outside you may think this is a chain restaurant but don't be fooled.  This place is an authentic JAPANESE restaurant with amazing quality and variety.  A little hidden and secret place-- we loved this place so much my husband went on Wednesday this week and returned on Saturday.  Having visited Japan many times, we can spot an authentic Japanese restaurant-- not just one that caters to Americans with their offering of hundreds of rolls (with mozzarella and everything fried).  Prices are amazing-- like Happy Hour price but offered all the time.  AND amazingly enough, they offer 2 for 1 Beer and house Sake AFTER 7-- yep after NOT before.  First time on Thursday -  we ordered the garlic edamame (on point), tuna tataki (fresh and delicious with fried garlic on top) and the tonkotsu ramen.  It may sound like they may offer too many different items to be good but not so.  The Ramen was probably one of the best I've had here since I moved here 3 months ago and I have gone to specialty Ramen only places.  The broth was rich but light and the noodles were the right amount of chewiness.  The noodles tasted homemade.  The pork actually had a grilled quality to it that most other ramen places do not have.  Now, I know where to go to satisfy my ramen crave.  One of the best buys is the buns.  They are only $2.50 and they are huge.  We tried the Pork Katsu ones and the pork was so flavorful, crunchy and melted in your mouth.  It was so good we had to order one more.  This is a must try.  Tonight - Saturday night - we went back.  We started with the Avocado Salmon Salad and it was the bomb.  With a light Yuzu dressing, lots of fresh Salmon sashimi and generous avocado , it was a price steal at 8 bucks!  We also had the Black Cod and grilled squid.  We have been to premier yakatori places in Northern Ca and this squid was better than any I have ever had.  Delicious, fresh and tender-- definitely another must try!  The Miso Black Cod was also flavorful and tender -- yum!  We also tried the Udon-- again amazing light, flavorful broth and satisfyingly chewy fresh udon.  We met the Japanese chef, Nagasan.  He was so polite and friendly.  The service is also very friendly and helpful.  Kevin helped us with both visits. Go try this secret, hidden gem.  You won't be disappointed.  I promise!

b7TqP54Gz4c2fZyFhzfYOQ.text: Overall the Ramen I just devoured tasted like any other ramen place I've been too, however the flavor was insanely enhanced by the decor and ambience that surrounded me. This place "explodes" with Japanese Culture. Felt like outside were the streets of Japan. Friendly service, quality of food, and the speed were all good in my favor. Will definitely be back!

FJiDnIEvgs6zFtlZKz44yg.text: Well the service is great. We were there on a Saturday at lunch and there was one waitress for the entire restaurant.  She did a fantastic job with serving, clearing tables, etc.  However, overall the food was okay nothing great.  Katsu curry was tasty but strong, katsudon was okay.  Gyoza was tasty. Big issue is cleanliness. Salt and pepper shakers and soy sauce plate were sticky and dirty.  Looks like cleanliness leaves something to,be desired.  With one waitress, how can she do everything and clean up too?  Also what looked like a counter for customers with utensils and napkins laid out has a curtain front of it but you can see supplies behind the curtain. Would hope they don't seat customers there, I wouldn't sit there and stare at a curtain while I'm eating.  So the place needs work definitely start with cleanliness.

ORSv53uhBmNKWvx8ujKDBA.text: Ordered the kitsune soba noodles with a side of potato croquette; the croquette was just right; not too hard and tasted just as I imagined. My soup broth was delicious, tofu was good and light, and the service was excellent. My other 2 friends also agreed that their meal was delicious. By the way, did I mention that the decor is wonderful! They also play only Japanese songs, which is perfectly fine with me.  I recommend giving this place a shot if you're in the area or in the mood for some noodles.

qF0N6o05ManQpufHzx1ADw.text: I went here, and after a short wait of about ten minutes I was seated.  We were lucky and beat the crowd.  Unlike others, the service was very fast.  The decor is like being in an out door street alley in Japan.  I liked the feel of it.  It kind of takes you away.  Decor A.  I got tonkotsu ramen.  The broth and noodles I'd give a B+, but they need to work on their toppings.  The Chasu, egg, and everything was good, but the bamboo tasted like the canned type.  If your you're going to use canned bamboo then just don't.  Also, they put what appeared to be saffron on top as well.  They could do without that.  Just keep it simple and yummy.  No need to make it fancy. Over all I like this place, but it seems to have a polerizing effect on people.  People either love it or hate it.  Hopefully that keeps it from getting to Monta's crowd level.  I still think Monta is the best in town.

ipbAI6_Ul4g14js_eifhMg.text: Place is GREAT. Unique decor intimate casual dining. $8-$9 for a wonderful flavored pork rice bowl, brought out on a tray just for you with a cup of miso soup & small salad. To kick it up a notch we were served lovely pieces of pickled radish & cucumber in bright color. While the flavor stood on its own without extras, we added spicy chili oil for a drop of heat. It was delightful & reasonably priced making a filling & flavorful meal. The waitress was friendly, efficient, and helpful in suggesting popular meals. We also learned this franchise is from the same owners who have brought Oishe Sushi, Sparklings, and a few other great restaurants to this Southwest corner of Vegas. Keep up the great offerings! Total bill including 2 dinners, 1 large saki, tax & tip $34

I love the decorations in here, it reminded me so much of when I went to Japan.   I ordered the tempura udon, it tasted like it was missing something so I asked for a side of ponzu sauce and mmmmm it make it 500% better! The noodles was cooked very well and the shrimp tempura was yummy.   I wanted to try their Chicken Curry but didn't want to order a lot of. The great thing is they have these small orders (rice bowl size) for under $5. I added corn to make it more my type of a curry bowl. I would have to say, the curry flavor was really delicious. It wasn't too strong and didn't over power the whole dish. The bowl could have used a little more chicken but other than that, I recommend it.   The environment is pretty intimate. The chairs/tables are near one another so if your heading here on a date, it's nice but don't be shy with your conversations cause everyone will hear you lol  Enjoy!

gj5bLpd3EMcfm2F9MOOE9Q.text: I was just driving around and noticed the big fancy noodles sign, so I decided to go and see what it's all about. Their lot was full of cars so I assume it is trending. When I walk-in, I felt this whole traditional Japanese scenery like I'm in a movie where ninjas will pop out. What caught my eyes right away was the display of paper lanterns hanging on the ceiling. The restaurant's lighting is dim, so it gives that intimate feeling with your partner or your food if you like your privacy that way lol.  It also brings out the beauty in all the lanterns hung above. I also found the bar unique too! It looks like a traditional outdoor food cart.     After walking in, I was immediately seated and provided a menu. She brought out water without me requesting it, as it should be standard. She gave me some time to look at the menu and asked if I had any questions regarding. There item selections because it was my first time. She recommended a noodle bowl with a rice ball side order that compliments my main dish.      I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen Bowl $12, a beef rice ball and crab mix rice ball $5 (2 pcs). The orders came out quick and hot, leaving my wait time a satisfactory  She was also quick to provide the spices and sauces for my meal. Communication was there and her ability to see cues on the customers needs was great.     I would definitely like to come back and make this my "go to spot" because it offers so much more on the variety of noodle bowls along with the many amazing appetizers. The bonus for me was also the spacious and private seating and more tables compared to most noodle places, so I don't feel crammed here.

Xum3cdZhcoAm-MfUmZxQ9Q.text: Overall taste was good but I was definitely taken back by the service and the food presentation. We got sat and it took a solid 20 minutes if not longer to get our order taken.   I ordered vegetable tempura and it was not what I was expecting at all. They deep fried a leaf in which my brother ate and said tasted like pure oil.   I ordered the kake udon (udon with tempura flakes) and added an egg. When it got delivered, the tempura flakes were mushed and looked gross, the egg was also missing. When I mentioned the missing egg the waitress told me that what I ordered doesn't come with an egg. Which I knew and is why I ordered an add-on egg. When she brought the egg, it was really cold.   The gyoza & mini curry rice bowl was the best thing I had tonight.   When we gave the waitress our checks, (2 cards & 2 cash payments), I felt like it took longer than normal to get the checks back. When I first looked, our waitress was closing out our checks. When I looked the second time she was standing somewhere else talking to a customer when there was other servers around.   On the check, we were already charged tip. Not sure if it's mentioned on the menu for 6 or more people, it's possible I missed that. I was taken by surprise when I received my check though.

E3Af9anK-OXcC0Xffjnd4w.text: After all the times that I've been to the southwest side to find a place to eat or run errands, I've always told myself I'm going to try this place out. Now, I can finally check mark it off my list. :]  The restaurant itself is nicely decorated and I love how they stuck with the theme of an old town Japanese noodle vendor. It looks as though it has warped into a lil nook on the southwest side of town. The high ceiling makes the place look so open. And when you look up at all the hanging lights and decor, it makes you feel like you're stuck in a dream. Corny? Well, just trust me... and LOOK UP. ;]  The service was great and I have no complaints about the food or wait time. Their menu is really simple and they've broken it down to mini appetizers, ramen, hot/cold noodle dishes, poke bowls, and rice platters. I tried the Tonkatsu ramen and my friend had the Gyudon (See the menu on Yelp for pics and descriptions). Both were really good! The portions were just right for the price and the presentation of the meals were nothing fancy. We also ordered the Honey Bread for dessert and it was a nice lil treat to top off our meals.  Would I come back to this place? Yes, but only if I'll be in the area. There are a lot of equally great noodle/ramen houses as well as poke bowl restaurants all around Vegas, so they need to add just a little something extra to the menu to make me want to drive this far. But all in all, a nice lil stop for a simple meal. :]

Q2zCyb_gLfvCOuqxcyW6HQ.text: Food was okay. Service was terrible.   Was so excited to try this place. After viewing the menu, we were already planning our return trip to the restaurant.   Ordered two appetizers: tofu steak and kimchi bun.  The kimchi bun was recommended by our server.  Took one bite and it was way too fishy and bun was stale and hard.  Told our server that we didn't care for it and to take it away.   Tofu steak was really good, loved the sauce and the bean sprouts.   Next, we ordered two entrees.  Spicy tonkotsu ramen and king tonkotsu.   After our appetizer, the ramen arrived. No tonkotsu.  Waited 5 minutes. No tonkotsu. Waitress noticed and said something about my entree coming right up.   Waited another ten minutes. Finally the king tonkotsu arrived explained to the server that my fiancee's ramen is now cold because we've waited 15 minutes for the tonkotsu to arrive. He said he'd tell our server.   She never showed up to the table until the end to drop the check.   The king tonkotsu was pretty good. Perhaps a bit over cooked, but it was absolutely enjoyable.   Got the bill and had to pay for the kimchi bun we sent back.   All in all, a terrible experience with slow inattentive service.  Too many places to eat in town. Will not be back.

zk-nn_XepOVb1enuQtpzDA.text: I love the inside of this establishment. It's very spacious and you don't have to worry about being too close to the other patrons. The decoration for Omoide definitely tops all the ramen places I've been to.  As far as food is concerned, this place isn't my go-to for ramen. Something about their base for the tonkotsu ramen is off to me. Out of all the ramen places I visit, their tonkotsu is my least favorite. The texture on the noodles aren't up to par with the other place I frequent either. I've also tried their takoyaki and it's alright to me.   Service here though is very good. You are always waited on very quickly, whether it be to ask how the food is or if drinks need to be refilled, they're on top of it. While this place isn't my favorite, some of my friends love this place and I can understand why.

ZbqnSs9s9SzIWJS4IUi5Ng.text: Stumbled upon a new favorite!  Omoide (, Japanese for "memories") is perfectly located on Rainbow blvd. to catch our attention enough to draw us in.  We were actually on the way to another spot, and because I don't often find myself in this part of town, I just had to try.    Once inside, the center ceiling lights will catch your eye, then you look around and now find yourself outside a Japanese village. From the building designs on the wall, the windows decorated like awnings, and the seated-bar section like a street cart, the interior decor is beautifully crafted atmosphere.  Like the name says, they serve poke bowls and variations of Japanese noodles.  Today I'm having an appetizer with ramen.  Next time I need to try the poke, or even the udon or soba (which are two of my other favorite Japanese noodles, not found often in Vegas).    Karaage ($5.50) - Japanese-style fried chicken bites.  Great but a little thin on the fry imo.  Tonkotsu ($7.50) - a classic bowl which every ramen spot offers.  Omoide's version nails it.  Thin noodles, flavorful broth, no overwheming oil, and compared to other ramen joints, at a good price.  The end result was a delicious experience by means of a surprising stumble.  I'm glad I found this place.  When I'm back in the area, I want to go straight to Omoide.

gaI8hxzbeXD-9dCDuqix4A.text: I'm half Japanese. My moms full and my grama from Japan is visiting. Alot of koreans up show Japanese restaurants (what's up with that!?). But my parents concluded, it's either a Japanese running it as the head, or a Korean who lived in Japan and learned. I've been to wannabe Japanese restaurants and I can tell. Any who, whoever it is, they nailed it. The most subtle nuisances. Like the way the tempura is fried. Good job omoide (means memory).

UWGWa5ljE_ZK_LtL9YPPDA.text: FINALLY! What I consider as a bowl of noodles in a noodle shop. I ordered noodles in pork broth, with a small side of plain white rice. I had my spices on the side so I could make them spicy to taste. The bowl of noodles came in a giant noodle bowl, with pork that had been rolled, and tied, seared, and slice into slim round disks. There was a boiled egg half open faced, some other yummy vegetables, and a small sheet of seaweed, which I like very much. The broth was brown and looked like someone had poured a little milk into it, which of course, they hadn't. I used the small bowl of plain white rice to cleanse my pallet every now and then so I could enjoy that, "first bite" feeling throughout the meal. I had tried a noodle shop in Hawaii, but I couldn't eat it. I had to get my money back and leave. I've ordered many bowls of noodles since then, and this place finally had what I was looking for. The noodles were a little softer and bigger. Good flavor. Most noodles in a shop I can't tell the difference between those and the little 20 cent dried squares you get at Walmart. These were better. The broth was delicious. I slurped down the whole giant bowl, one little spoonful at a time. It was a very satisfying experience. And, at $9.50, I thought it was a bargain. I'm getting over a cold, so I needed me a good hot bowl of salty, spicy noodles to slide down my poor throat, and this was very rewarding! I will eat there on a regular basis. Every time I'm in the mood for a bowl of noodles.

wUCRDxNvM4yvE_ubVOleug.text: So the other day, I went to check out a nice ramen noodle shop called Omoide off of south Rainbow and Robindale for lunch. I do like the fact that it is pretty close to my work......but what about everything else?  THE DECOR (4 out of 5) It was pretty nice walking into this new restaurant. Lots of seating and really high vaulted ceilings made it feel really spacious. That and a lot of Japanese touches (even Japanese ads) that made it feel kind of fun.  THE SERVICE (4 out of 5) Pretty good service from the wait staff here. Didn't really have to wait too long to get our food and refills on my water were plentiful.  THE FOOD (4 out of 5) So, let's get down to it, shall we? I had ordered an app of their karaage (think Japanese fried chicken nuggets) which was pretty good although, I kind of like the karaage from Fukumimi better. And then I had the Tonkotsu Shoyu ramen (like I usually get from Monta) and it was pretty good too. The veggies and the pork chashu were good, but as far as the flavor of the actual ramen broth, I really prefer Monta's ramen broth instead. Maybe it's because I'm a big salt kind of guy, I dunno. The good part though for Omoide is that they have a lot of stuff on the menu like udon or soba noodles (both hold and cold), katsu don, etc. So, I'm looking forward to trying out their other dishes.  *UPDATE* I went to Omoide for lunch again last week and had the Tonkatsu Curry Don, which was really good.   OVERALL (4 out of 5) So, if you're in the Southwest part of town and are looking for some good eats, be sure to check out Omoide. However, if you're looking for the best ramen out there and don't mind waiting, then Monta or Monta Chaya (in my opinion) are where you should go.

I don't like overly spicy, I feel it hides the flavors of the food.  Miso Ramen: My husband had this and loved it. I might get it next time but I loved the curry so much I'm not sure. [SERVICE] Upon emptying my water glass it took less than 30 seconds for them to notice and offer a refill. Nice. The servers were very attentive and friendly. Lots of smiles here. aKG_ilKmI13di1DozgNlcA.text: First time we came we got the Zaru (cold noodles and Katsu Don. Pretty good and light.  Today was a little busier. Today was different. There's 4 dirty tables around us...too much work for two people. Witnessed 4 walkouts! Yikes.   We'll come back. Maybe when it's not so busy.

J1Jovle0yt9hY3ru18ieeA.text: I love this place. I always get the Ebi Fry Curry Don. The portions are on point and the food is so delicious and so filling. This place is one of my favorites. The poke  bowl is awesome, fresh ahi. My family and I love it. We come at least 1-2 month as a treat!

C_KnMuEu4KEuCdK1zAfAlQ.text: This place is an in between-er. There was a few things I liked a lot but the others were ehh. Let's start with the bad ones. The tonkatsu don was okay. It didn't taste special or anything. The Tonkatsu sauce was already on the meat which made it soggy. I recommend asking for the sauce in the side. The miso soup was one of the worst I've ever tasted, mostly because it tasted like hot water.   On the upside, we ordered the Buta shio buttkake and it's amazing! In fact, we loved it so much that we ordered a side of noodles to add to the broth. The sesame ice cream was also one of the best I've ever tasted. I'll definitely get a scoop every time I go.   We wanted to start with the gyoza but the waitress forgot to ring it in, I guess. We didn't feel like eating it anymore.   I guess if you're gonna go here, try the Buta shio buttkake and the tonkatsu with sauce on the side!

2rjVAodIvPmAoR-6GpEp1w.text: Fantastic poke.  Had a large bowl with tuna, salmon and octopus on top of greens and loaded with extras.  Quality fish and excellent service. We'll be back often.  As a bonus they have 2 for 1 beer and sake after 7 pm

There is also a great selection of appetizers and dons (rice bowls) if you're not feeling ramen.

qkX5NtJkPI_jp9TGNWyhkg.text: A ramen restaurant near home is always good, especially with the cold weather. Great deal for lunch $12 (ramen + side dish + drink). D58RGg2KpapxPVKm5YkCuA.text: I was glad to hear a new ramen/udon/soba/rice bowl place had opened in the Southwest part of Vegas. I ordered the chicken karaage and shrimp udon. I had one of my friend's gyoza and sampled the Spicy Tonkotsu Shoyu ramen.   Chicken Karaage was decent but I would have liked more seasoning. I hate to say this but I was really disappointed in my udon. The broth was too light & thin and had a weird, indescribable taste to it. I couldn't figure out what was in it or what was missing. I didn't care for the udon consistency either. I prefer the noodles to be chewy, soft, and thick. Sadly, I've had better $1 udon from the market. My husband said his ramen was just OK.  The service was good and the food came out in a reasonable manner. I didn't finish my udon and thought of driving to a fast-food joint after but decided to eat dessert at home instead. I'm not sure if I would return to try the other items. I'll read the reviews and see how things pan out.

ADJ0_Z3VoN0fCJvOGuC6Aw.text: It's hard to find a great Ramen place that also serves great soba and udon. I'm so glad we found the right place! This restaurant is lovely, with a succinct menu featuring a handful of apps, noodle combos, and bowls. They serve Ramune soda, which is a plus. We started with the typical apps - tempura and karagge. Both were very good. My cold soba with tempura was fantastic. You can't go wrong with soba on a hot day.   You'll probably bump into me at a corner table on the regular. I'll be the one with 4 orders of tempura apps and soba noodles.

SWkTTNvXXbMubpNHFgl_3A.text: First visit here, I believe it just opened not too long ago. We arrived at 2:30.  Environment: The inside is clean and ventilation is great, no smell from the kitchen at all, especially no frying oil smell.  Service: Very good. We were acknowledged and seated immediately. Menu and water was provided before the server walked away to another table. The food came out quickly and our server came back numerous times to clear off emptied dishes, refilled our drinks, and made sure everything was fine.  Food: We ordered, Gyoza, Cold Tofu, Potato Croquette, Edamame, Kitsune (Bean curd Udon), and Buta Shio Bukkake (Pork belly Soba). Potato Croquette was fried perfectly, crispy and doesn't fall apart. Kitsune, the noodles were great. Soft yet chewy, just like udon should be. The soup, however, was a little saltier than it should be for this dish. Buta Shio Bukkake, the Soba was made perfectly and sauce was good too. I must say, the pork belly was made very very good, crispy with lots of flavor.  We will definitely be back to try other things on the menu. Donburi (rice bowl)next.

hMerXhzhAj3I2OIwfKgkDQ.text: This place just opened up near our house. I love ramen noodles and my gf loves tempura, so we decided to stop by for lunch. The location is easy to find and parking isn't an issue. We were treated nicely by the young kids running the place.   We started out with Pan fired dumpling and the our chosen dishes that I previously mentioned. The shrimp tempura came in quickly. However I had to wait 10-15 minutes before my Ramen was delivered.   Tempura shrimp with curry was alright. Lacked proper breaking and the curry was too thick.  Ramen broth was nice but expect very small amount of noodles, so order extra noodles if u are hungry. Dumpling were good, same as other places.   Overall it a good place to get ramen in south west if you don't want to drive to Chinatown. But I'd rather go to Sora or Tonkotsu Kiyoshi for my Japanese fix.

bnmvzPzsFkXbzzgEBQKuuQ.text: Beyond thrilled to have a ramen shop in Southwest!  Can't tell you how many times we have dreaded the drive to Jinya / Monta but couldn't live without Ramen!    The decor is so adorable with Japanese accents. The restaurant only had a few patrons when we arrived, but my daughter spotted a couple of seats at their bar, so that's where we enjoyed our first Omoide meal. :)  Menus were "served" on clipboards.  Extensive menu for a little place!  I had a hard time deciding what to order, but being that it was an unusually cold day in May, I knew I wanted a hot bowl of noodles!  Although I was excited to try the ramen, I ordered the Shrimp Tempura Udon and my daughter ordered the Tonkatsu Miso Ramen (I knew she would be able to spare a few bites for me to try their ramen noodles as well).  We also had the garlic edamame appetizer.  Everything was really delicious and plated (bowled) beautifully!  Our soup was not super hot which was a little disappointing, but not enough for us to send it back. We ate it anyway and honestly we were both very happy (and full) with our meal!    Of course their service was a little scattered, which is expected of a new restaurant on only its second day of business, but I'll be back to check them out after they've had more time to get used to their own menu + perfect their service.   Nonetheless, EXCITED to have a solid noodle option a few blocks from my house. Woohoo!

mIhitkQAVVYa5w1eE3OXwg.text: First of all, I am really excited that there is finally a ramen place here in the Southwest! So when we saw that this place opened, we tried it right away.   I learned that "omoide" means "memories, recollections" in Japanese which is reflected well within the interior of this ramen place. The design reminds me of a street in Japan where you find a random ramen spot and discover that it's a diamond in the rough. It is very well-lit (love the paper lanterns!) and spacious. I like that the windows are big letting more light into the place. Most ramen places make it so that their interiors are dark.  It makes me feel a little claustrophobic sometimes. The ambiance inside Omoide is homey and comforting.   The food here is decent. Not the best. It is hard not to compare it to Monta Choya. Their broth for their ramen is pretty bland. I think that is a good thing. It is refreshing to have a ramen place where you can control how salty you want your broth to be.  The portions are big so you get your money's worth.   Overall, this is still a pretty good ramen place. They are new so there is always room for improvement.

9-TiXUEjONH9c_A8-pvoHw.text: Came in here the other night craving soup. Had not heard or read anything about the place before coming (which is rare for me considering I am an avid yelper). The atmosphere and decor was very cool, made to look like you're in Japan. Restaurants these days are becoming very creative I must say. I ordered the Spicy tonkatsu and the boyfriend ordered the pork katsu bowl. Overall, I'd say the ramen was medicore,  no where near as full bodied and flavorful as Monta Ramen. The Katsu was fairly good, and came with miso soup and salad. Service was good as well. Wasn't wowed by this place but  not bad.

gcTLfHZQXH4xoo727Q68zQ.text: They have all the ramen and rice bowl section you need. I love the unique set up. They have all kinds of flavors and you chose what you want in your ramen. My favorite by far is the car just because I can munch on something and not feel like I'm full and taste delicious. We been here quite a few times and will be returning we haven't tried much on the menu but they all look great and customer service is on point

6uL1QyashLOxAmjgFrjp5g.text: I have to say that ever since I left Los Angeles many moons ago, I found myself having an occasional  Yoshinoya craving. I don't know what possessed me  to pull over and try this restaurant out ....ok, it was the cool looking building and a sign that said "Noodles", but I'm absolutely glad I did!  I went in there with miso ramen in mind. As I was looking over the menu, I came across this Gyu Don. The picture looked familiar, so I read the description . It said 'thinly sliced beef with onions in a sweet soy sauce over rice.' Say wuut!?!? Naturally, I ordered it and OMG!!! It hit home! It reminded me of the beef bowl from yoshinoya but way, way better!!! I was totally in heaven! Sprinkled some of that red pepper and it was bomb.   For appetizer I had this chasu bun thing. Looked like a taco but with bread. Very tasty!   I had to give it 4 stars because as much as I liked the gyudon, I can't justify paying 9 bucks for it. Maybe if they lowered the price to $7, I'd be down to go back and get more, but as of now, I got my fix and I'm good.

Lsmd0kzk2LP2i3VgRldAAA.text: I'd never had proper ramen before coming to Omoide Noodles, and they set the bar very high! The decor is beautiful, the staff is friendly, and the food is absolutely delicious. I've been here a couple times already, and definitely will be back when I'm craving Japanese cuisine again!

hV_EF3d29PL73EksX2TpbA.text: Always fast, polite and delicious. I get the tonkatsu ramen and it js always top notch!

njz7uD2PGcfY5Yr7iVJKBA.text: Have been here several times. Food is good! Tried a couple different things each time coming here. They have a great selection of items from rice bowls to soba noodles.   Service on the other hand is so-so.... even when its not super busy. Some of the waiters and waitress are a little forgetful, and having to ask another another staff member.   But overall experience was great!  Items ordered on this visit:  Spicy tonkatsu ramen- not very spicy at all, but tasty. Katsu Don- very good portion and flavors are good Buta Shio with Soba

8uUyRzAFDP_0yqvHvwzl7g.text: My husband and I like to come here a lot because there are plenty of different options, and we love Asian restaurants near our area.   Their gyoza is amazing. It seems to be partially steamed and partially fried. The best part of it is the shredded green onions on top, it really makes it taste better.   The last time we were there, they gave us a free bowl of udon noodle soup with what appeared to be tempura crumbles in it. The broth tasted like agedashi tofu. It was very thoughtful of them and delicious.   Their ramen is ok, but that's the least of my worries because I know this is not a complete "ramen spot"   They also have curry dishes that are always good. My favorite is their mini chicken curry bowl. Although the chicken is not crispy, it's still the perfect portion for a quick snack to enjoy with your other dishes.   They also have a buy one get one drink special at certain times for those of you that like sake or beer.

7plT_zirHiGbDuhGU9eM4Q.text: I love this place! It's my favorite ramen place in the area. The ramen is so flavorful and the portions are big. The pricing of the ramen is very affordable $9 per bowl! Every time I come here the service is okay. While the servers are very friendly seems that they always forget something. We have to either ask for refills or forget our drinks. Although service isn't the best I'll still be a regular here.

photos.caption: Photo of Omoide Noodles & Bowls - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkotsu Miso Ramen

JJ6DaYkzOg1r2a4DWaMQKw.text: This place is even better in my opinion than the Ramen houses we have in downtown LA. I fed my whole family and I for under 40 bucks and it was honestly the best ramen I've had in country.   The spicy needs to be kicked up a notch however with the chili oil and red powder at your table you can go as hot as you need. Also I recommend ordering extra noodle if you're hungry or want to share. It will cost you three dollars for twice the food!   The lunch box is also a great value so if you can capitalize on that it will help your wallet.   The staff is very helpful as well so if you are new to ramen houses (I envy you) don't feel intimidated or dumb for asking questions about what is what they are there to help you and they do.   My family and I will most definitely be back the next time we are in Vegas!

qIMVRgxxuhb2lUMCRBgejg.text: My daughter suggested this restaurant because she comes here often. My husband and I received the wrong order. They corrected that issue. And then my daughter received the wrong order as well. The waitress argued with my daughter, telling her that she was wrong. The ramen I had, I couldn't finish. It's barely average. JINYA ramen bar is leagues better. I will never come here again. Packaged Top Ramen tastes better.  So disappointed

-NKwZPCtlW4CzLgzv-mc9Q.text: Checked this place out and want to come back already ! The ambiance and environment is great. Its nicely decorated inside with a cozy welcoming feel, tumblr vibey lmao. The servers were nice. I love their business hours, and huge but not too big menu choice with great pictures and brief descriptions.  Let's not forget about the food !!! I ordered the spicy tonkatsu ramen and it was delicious ! I just wish it was spicier. We also had the beef tataki,  perfectly seared and red in the center in a delicious citrus-y ponzu sauce garnished with fried garlic chips and red onions ! The tuna tataki was alike except the sauce was thicker and spicier, less citrus-y if I remember right. The miso blackened cod was so tender and sweet and so delicious, only question about it is it's small portion compared to the picture in the menu ! Last but not least, the grilled squid was great as well ! Even though it didnt have a sauce on it, it was still deliciously flavored and yummy.   Our bill rang up about $60 for four, what a steal ! The prices on their items are affordable ! Cant wait to come back and try more of their delicious food !

4FBGhh3kEB2zQH61vAOMyA.text: Variety: 5/5 Taste: 4.5/5 Customer Service 5/5  I've been here a handful of times but not enough times as I wish I would have gone living across the street the last 1.5 years. We stopped in the last two nights and had EXCELLENT service from both waiters. They were polite, attentive and very friendly which nowadays is very hard to find. It had a variety of different foods. We had the spicy short rib ramen and pork Katsu curry last night. I had the spicy tonkatsu ramen tonight and my husband ordered the Japanese pasta. We also ordered karrage. Everything was great! I highly recommend you stop in. It's a nice lunch/dinner spot!

d5_24muGm3mPJlgtb4dOnA.text: Still going strong as a maturing noodle shop here in the booming SW of Vegas.  I get the traditional Buta Shio even on hot days.  The broth is killer and the soba is usually perfectly pliant, soft and slurpable.  There's some sushi on offer and I might try it next time in a combo with a bowl.  Poke also looks promising.

1DYkfTT9eZlhfjrcWzCwGA.text: Really great, inexpensive ramen and bowl options. Broth is extremely flavorful without an overly powerful pork flavor. Quick service and neat dining. Great value and open late.

nbrmDPyRiJ8ycXFK8AXGGA.text: Been here 5xs now.  Dined in 4xs and took take out tonight at midnight because no one else was open.   Customer service is awful. No personality and seem stressed being the only one on the floor.   I ordered the shrimp don and my mom ordered the tempura udon. Both were awful. I asked for udon noodles and we got home and found out we had cold soba noodles in a cold square instead hot udon.   Won't be back.  Best to dine in.  1 Star for late night hours.

EXcfYyv46qMv_eoIFQbxdA.text: Super cute place, when you walk in you will notice the high ceiling and lanterns beautifully hanging.  First timers here on a Sunday morning a little after opening time. The place was pretty empty aside from two parties. We were a party of 6. Tables are small and so are the spaces between the tables on the floor of the dining room. If it were a full house, I could see it getting right for people to walk through or around.  The room is lined with a few booths which I thought looked cute.  Didn't need to use the restroom but my kids and husband did. The husband said the restroom was gross, which is too bad since the dining area looked nice.  Got our menus and water right away, it took a while for the server to come back to us to get our orders. I think she was the only one. I was disappointed to hear that it would take an hour to get the spicy tan tan ramen I wanted, so I ordered a regular one. My kid got a tonkatsu bowl and we were disappointed again to see that the portion was so small. We tried to order a side of tonkatsu alone but they wouldn't let us do that. They said the register didn't have that option. I'm sure they could've put it in as a miscellaneous charge and write a note somewhere.  We thought it was funny how all of the cooked foods came out before the poke bowl.  Refills on our water kept coming till business picked up a little. Then when we ordered our dessert, Honey Toast, no one came to clear the table so we piled everything up on the ends. Even as they served us our desert and dropped off the check, our used dishes still took up space at the ends and our glasses never refilled despite there being another server on the floor besides the one when we first arrived.  Food was good but not so good/unique that I'll be craving for it. I like that they have a big selection of items and they even have a eating challenge too. I wish I go to taste the spicy broth.  Don't think I'll be back, but will probably recommend to anyone who lives on this side and loves ramen.

oQEZ61h231GMoy3WxW1RAQ.text: The food is amazing. Is our go to place for Ramen and other delicious food. The have great poke and different appetizers and other bowls if you do not want the ramen.

47Ki6cFO7B8_JXIfdtQ1Kw.text: I took my family here and I'm glad I did! I thank my youngest son or I wouldn't have known about this place. The place has good food and I'm definitely be coming back here. Want to take your family or even your relatives & friends...this would be a good place to take them.

F8oB79CP2UH0VOymj5E8Ew.text: So much goodness here that I am going to have to come back to be able to take it all in.   I really like the design inside. I feel like I'm in an old Japanese village restaurant but it still keeps a modern feel to it. Very cool.   Then there's the awesome variety of menu items. There is a lunch special too but I'm here for an early dinner. They have a couple of Katsu items. Tonkatsu. Bowls. Noodles. All the favorites. And the price is totally reasonable.   How is this not the hottest place this side of the Pacific Ocean??   I guess it's tucked away and kept a little secret but not for long. It's too good not to try.

1xXHT0U-Pa-nXAFyspqRsw.text: Me and my husband have passed by this place several times and gave it a try today. We had karaage appetizer, ten-don (tempura donburi) and tonkotsu ramen.  My husband has been on a search for good tonkotsu, and we are happy to say this place filled his needs! I cannot speak for him, but the chashu was tender, broth was perfect and came with thin noodles as it should (according to him).  My tendon came with 3 shrimps, nasu, shishito, kabocha (pumpkin) and a perfect hanjyuku-tamago (egg)!!  It was a double thumbs up for not only having potato croquette but also having pumpkin croquette!! Oh, and Orion beer of course.   Their interior is amazing, and almost reminded us of a yatai, and gives the ambiance of sitting outdoor.  Clean overall, and the staff was extremely lovely with the smiles. :)   We hope to come back this week!!!

apMpGSZtm0GFqTp6glLXoQ.text: Short version of this review: If I can give zero star, I would. Please don't waste your time and money to come here. Long version of this review: I made a yelp account just to write this review. This is the worst taste I've ever had in a restaurant. I ordered Spicy Tonkotsu Miso Ramen, the broth tastes decent but the bamboo shoots taste horrible and smells gross. They don't taste fresh, they taste like canned bamboo shoots you can buy at China Town. The thing that upsets me most was the Buta Shio Bukkake. My girlfriend ordered it and it was nothing but udon noodles in clear soup with three extremely thin slices of burned grill pork and three sticks of green onion. The soup tastes like boiled water with oil and burned smells, and the worst thing is that it costs $9! I will attach pictures at the end of the review. It was so bad that I had to ask the server to take it back. The restaurant let me order something else instead. I ordered Chicken Karage Don, which tastes blahhh at best. The chicken tastes so bland and the miso soup that came with it tastes horrible. The tofu in the miso soup tastes like it hasn't been washed prior to cooking. I don't understand how they can serve food that tastes so bad to customers and charge this price. It's ridiculous. Overall, definitely avoid this restaurant at all costs if you don't want to ruin your appetite and waste your time and money. I would not even eat the food there again even for free.

d2gCwmXZOpx7wgF_VySlPA.text: In Vegas, it seems like the benchmark is Monta Ramen on Spring Mt. so I'm going to review this place in comparison.   1. Environment: with plenty of room and vaulted ceilings the environment is very nice.  2. Service: I didn't request for a lot and I don't have complaints 3. Soup base: I actually like the soup here more. The flavor of the Tonkotsu was more subtle and not as overbearing with the salt.  4. Noodles: It tastes store bought, nothing special.  5. Chashu pork: Compared to Monta, unremarkable. It was a bit course and flavorless in comparison.  6. Price: 1 bowl of Ramen with 2 toppings was $11  Overall, I will come back again. It's a good lunch spot on this side of town.

uT4BF92NEqMhExukdF0nYA.text: Sooooo my boyfriend and I just left this place completely dissatisfied. Being a huge fan of Monta and Sora, we wanted to try this place out since it's closer to our houses.   First, service took FOREVER. And I'm not exaggerating. A couple seated next to us, left because their dishes were taking too long as well. Anyways, it took them twenty minutes to give us our first ramen dish. And I had to wait an additional fifteen minutes for my pork belly miso bowl to arrive. And lastly, the gyoza came after another five or so minutes. And there was no communication between the servers at all. We got the bill twice at the end of our meal.   If the service wasn't bad enough, the food was below mediocre. The broth for the miso ramen tasted like it came from powder. The so-called udon noodles looked and tasted like hydrated ramen noodles. Both bowls were oily as well.   Definitely NEVER going back. Drive to Monta or Sora instead!!!!

0OT5i028lTpzvl09AKnWCg.text: So happy to have a ramen house in Southwest. Of course before coming in, we had to check out the yelp reviews and the menu. I was so excited to see chicken karaage on their menu! I had a karaage bowl and my husband had tonkotsu ramen. Their ramen is surprisingly good! It isn't salty like majority of ramen places. To our disappointment, karaage was just o.k. Nothing beats the original we have back in Japan. The chicken was very dry and lacking flavor.   Food took a while to get to us but the guy who served us was very quick and attentive! I love the atmosphere! It felt like we were on the streets of Japan. Definitely coming back and recommending this place to friends and family.   Finally! We won't have to drive all the way to Spring Mountain to get good ramen. Hopefully our future visits here will be just as good.

2w0sT-wcQY3DrrNVn5BvBA.text: This noodle house is a waste of your money.... Sorry to say but my instant ramen noodle tasted better then what I ordered here..... I ordered tempura udon noodle soup... Xt0T0cjJua0EBKpC5hX2fQ.text: Decor: Very cute! They had something visually interesting in every corner and the ceiling.  Layout: I hate the entrance!  Open the doors to tables. Customers (including myself) stop at the entrance looking left and right for the hostess stand. There is none. Food: I only had the zaru soba (cold buckwheat noodle) and a Calpico.  So it's hard to judge the quality of food based on an easy dish. I guess I'll say it was acceptable. Service: Servers were polite and there were no long waiting periods. Menu: OMG There are so many different types of Japanese food on this menu I wonder what they can handle it.  One order could be ramen and the next could be a katsudon. The cook(s) have to be really talented to switch gears like that. Finally, I found several misspellings on the menu.  I addressed it to the server and he said he will pass it along to the manager. Overall, it was fine.  I live close by so I will most likely visit again.

pi170FxEe3_JIiBHGA1plw.text: This place is exactly what we needed on this side of town. I can see why the harsh reviews, it isn't the usual tiny, overcrowded, divy place that cool douchy hipsters would prefer. Instead it's roomy, properly decorated, staff is very nice and the food is solid. Can't go wrong with the ramen here. Very good, and the waitress took her time to go over the menu and explain it to us. That to me goes a very long way. According to some of the reviews, they must've had a bumpy start when they first opened ("waited this long for my menu", or "this long for my food" god forbid that happens on a grand opening! Pfft) but they are on point right now. I'll be back again for sure.

hcCYrhdcGWi3H2MAimUm7A.text: First off I want to say how happy I am for such a great ramen place to be so close to home.   As soon as you walk in you'll notice the detailed decor. It's super cute and very well planned out. It reminds me of a little Japanese village you might see illustrated in a book or in a old Japanese film. It's not just the counter seating but if you look up you will see the lanterns and the set up they have in the nooks of the walls.   Then there's the food. I love most things spicy so when I first came I ordered the spicy tonkatsu miso ramen with an egg even though you have to order it separately, I gotta have an egg. Lol That was delicious and now here for the second time I couldn't wait to have it again. It's not spicy to where you can't enjoy your meal. It's just the right amount of spice, because they know that's why you ordered it. I love the noodles, always soft and just the right size. The toppings in the ramen are what make the broth more flavorful. As you eat you can taste all the different things but at the same time nothing over powers another. We also tried the umeboshi Onigiri, which is pickled plum inside a rice ball. This brought me back to my grandmother. Being raised in a Japanese house, when we were sick we were given umeboshi Onigiri and tea, it brought back memories. We also ordered the gyoza, honestly it's nothing to be excited about. It's a fried pot sticker, something I feel you can make at home.   My overall feel for this place is amazing. Love, love, love it!! The waitresses are super nice and very friendly. Always making sure everything is alright and filling up your cup. Brought my brother back this time only for him to love it too. I will continue to be coming back and bringing more people.

ExX_Of2QOcNi3-MTcUxSVg.text: Located in an awkward area of the shopping center. Pay attention to where you park, you might park in the back thinking that's the front.   I got off work super late and I wanted food. Saw that they have happy hour, Buy one get one free on beer/sake. I was like, why not? I had a long day at work.  Ordered the grilled squid and chicken karaage don. Ok, the squid was alright, grilled and no seasoning to it. The chicken karaage was a little off. Especially the breading. I guess that's their take on it.   But other than that, service was good and would come back for another HH drink.

iVbdTEZMTIYa5tXK8SEhvg.text: Cute decor and theme.  Above average price for dishes especially if you're getting any sushi or poke.  The soup broths are ok, not as great as some top ramen houses in the valley like Monta, Sora, or JINYA in terms of flavor.  Of course, there is never a wait here so that could be a fallback option for some.

UUex3ypXgMMu7Ns95gc0hg.text: Open until 1am! Yay! Love that this ramen place is near us and away from Chinatown. I liked their ramen. I got the tonkotsu ramen and the flavor of the broth was very hearty and delicious. I liked that they include the bamboo in their ramen dish unlike some other ramen spots in Vegas. Whenever I've had ramen in Japan the bamboo shoots always came with. Also the chashu was very tender as well. I forgot to ask for an egg with my ramen though, didn't realize it didn't come with one. Oh well.   Service was excellent.  Happy hour drink specials were fun with the buy one, get one free beer and house sake special and the ramen was delish. First time here and definitely not my last.

6OxDmz9X80mxYW35iJsdzA.text: This spot is straight up dope. The prices are a serious value for how much food you get. A large poke bowl with as much as you want is only $12 it's ridiculous. You can order 3 different kinds of fish for the same price, and if you want even more it's only $2 extra. The tuna tataki was amazing with a little garlic, cilantro and spicy sauce. They even have sashimi. Lunch specials are an even better deal. The service is awesome, the atmosphere is cozy and chillaxed, and there's always customers but it never seems crowded. There's a lot of poke joints around LV but I don't know how it could get much better. Everyone is always super friendly and you never wait long for food.  I just started on the Whole 30 diet, and the menu here is super friendly to that. They have a pretty extensive menu that I haven't even started to explore yet, so I'm looking forward to that journey. And best of all, they stay open til 1 am if I get a jones for a big bowl of delicious fish. It's a 15 minute drive and I would make that trip 3 times a week because the food is so good. Check it out, you'll definitely come back for a second, third and fourth visit.

jk0OURYHxG1WTx5t3yi16w.text: I have been wanting to try this noodle place for quite a while. Today after leaving IKEA we had a chance.   A.  Where is everyone?  Came in on a Sunday at about 2:15 pm Amd it is nearly empty in this very good sized noodle shop with plenty of tables and space.    B.  Service - very nice and attentive staff. Friendly and quick.  C.  Choices. Love this menu.  From the rice dishes, to the noodles, ramen, soba and udon.  Both hot and cold noodles. They even have my favorite Zaru Soba noodles as well.  D.  The food. This is key and three star to me.   A.  Buta Shio Bukkake Cold Soba- of course I love soba and cold is best.  I first want to know where were the noodles?  They gave me a huge bowl and a small bit of soba.  The soba was perfectly cooked.  Enjoyed it quite a bit.  The grilled pork belly was well very grilled. I found it to be tough and the taste was not flavorful.  The sauce was strong.  Very strong taste.  I know they use Mirin for the sauce but it was over powering.   B. Tonkatsu Shoyu Ramen- my son ordered this and I had a few bites.  The sauce was very good, ramen just right.  My only issue is that the ramen was swimming in soup and I prefer that it is not.  C.  Hiyashi Chuka - these cold ramen noodles are very good and on a nice warm day just right.  Right amount of ramen and all the toppings were great.  The wifey ordered this and of course I stole some bites.  I look forward to ordering this in future.    I like this place, the size, the service.  The food could be slightly improved but  it it is good overall.  GK says check it out.

XtAgHri6lbI2zjwUow4tPw.text: I don't know why people gave not that good of a review for this place. My first impression when I walked in was "wow, what a cool looking little restaurant". Went here for dinner around 5pm, I was having cravings for some curry. I ordered the Ton Katsu Curry Don, it was about $10. Came with Miso soup and a side of salad with the combo, Not bad for a full meal. The chicken cutlet was crispy, and the curry sauce was tasty. I was still amazed with the ambience of this place. This restuarant is located where I call "little Chinatown" next to Oyhsi on Rainbow Blvd Rd.   Will come back again to try many more of their items like their karaage chicken plate. Will recommend to my friends looking for a quick bite of curry, they won't disappoint. Service was decent but never gave me a bad experience.

JPHfHT_CBFIPb2r6gfJhBQ.text: I've been meaning to try this places since it opened.   I must say that I'm a little disappointed......:( I mean who wouldn't want a great ramen place less then 5 minutes from your house? So.... When I went I was excited but disappointed with my first bite. :(  I got their hot green tea. It was pretty decent. But then again how can u mess up green tea?? OK traditional matcha tea is a whole different story...... Lol (4/5)  I got their onigiri as an app... It looked pretty... But the flavor was non existent. The daikon was salty salty salty...(2/5) but it helped the onigiri that was bland bland bland....:/ together they were OK... But the crab mix just had no flavor and the rice was overcooked so that it was on the mushy side and I'm sorry but who wants mushy rice in their onigiri?? (2/5)  I also got their tonkatsu shoyu.... And I know that shoyu is a Japanese soy sauce.... But still there should have been more balance in flavor. It was just salty salty salty. I'm seeing a trend here. Too much salt and not enough other flavors. It was not balanced at all. Did I eat it? Yes I did.... I was starving. :/ but did I enjoy it... Sadly no....:(   Service was ok seeing as how I was the only person there. :) but I still had to ask her for a refill on my tea (4/5)  Ambiance.... It was cute. Same layout as when it was Rice Traxx but better decorations! :) (5/5)  Will I return... Most likely no... I would rather drive to Jinya or to other ramen places in the Chinatown area.

5uE19mgnpYn0QeTOVrBrnw.text: This was genuinely a go to the spot for me. I couldn't even count the amount of people that I've introduced to this place, it'd be hard to calculate the hundreds (plural) of dollars I spent at this place overtime. Last night, both myself and my coworker were very disappointed.  It's almost religious I order the same thing at this place (The only exception is when I'm feeling dangerous and order a honey bread for dessert). It's always Ramen and a side order of shrimp tempura. The shrimp comes in a set of two for three dollars and while I'm personally not the biggest fan of the price, I pay it anyway every time because I just happen to love shrimp tempura. Last night, however... When I received my order, it was noticeably smaller to both myself and my coworker who comes with me all the time.   Seriously, if you look at my last review, it was five stars and I'm pretty sure I even mentioned it was arguably my favorite restaurant. Not anymore. I brought it to the waiter's attention upon delivery and he scoffed at me and said "they always come in this size." They don't... They seriously don't. If I was cheap and just trying to get free things, I would've complained that there is some hair in my soup or something. I've never complained here before in the countless times I've been here, i've always been polite to everybody. I've always been easy to please.   This is the one time (over a three dollar item) that I had ever spoken up about anything and I was argued with and scoffed at. I didn't even ask for them for free, I just wanted them exchanged for some regular sized shrimp if I was going to pay the three dollars I always pay for it. That type of guest service put enough of a bad taste in my mouth that I have become fairly confident I'm never going to come here again. This was a bill over $40 (including tip, because I'm not an animal) you would think more effort would have been placed forward to retain a VERY loyal guest's business but instead they are now trained to argue baby shrimps till their death.

zB0ZUmQBaL743v7_mWRniQ.text: The aesthetics of the place is really eye catching. The service was half decent. The waitress only brighten up until we ordered two of their special beers with peach and lychee flavor. Which were good.   The food though is a whole other story. The noodles were done right. Their soup doesn't have that umami flavor.. It's missing quite a lot. I wouldn't come here for their noodles.   IMO, their Chasu don bowl is probably the only I would come there for. The rice was just right paired with the sauce of the Chasu and pickled plum and radishes. Their rice bowls come with salad and miso soup. Their salad were sprinkled with a dash of yuzu to give it a citrus-y flavor.   The black sesame ice cream was just what was needed to make the meal feel complete. But overall,  I left feeling full but unsatisfied, the noodles lacked a lot of flavor and umami.

yceD0poeizzT_47s8waqrQ.text: Okay at best. Service was okay. Food was okay.  We came in for an evening snack. We were seated promptly. Waters were refilled at a decent rate and server was nice.  On to food. Beef tataki didn't stand out. Didn't get any sweetness or aroma from the garlic chips. The beef lacked savoriness, which made the acid stand our a bit much. The corn cheese was also okay. A bit of sweetness from the corn, but the cheese didn't impart any addition. The buta shio soba didn't really add up either. The soba was great, the pepper puree was great, even the grilled pork was great. The broth however was a little funky and didn't impart much. Two things that did stand out, however, were the chashu bowl and the croquette. The chashu bowl was melt in your mouth great. With the addition of umeboshi, the bowl left a satisfying feeling. The croquette was crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside (get this).  For dessert, get the black sesame ice cream. It was good.  Overall: Okay. Wouldn't go back anytime soon though.

oVy6E4E1RW8I98qss7JciQ.text: Another good option for ramen in southwest Vegas.  It seemed as if Omoide gives you a very easy-going ramen experience.  The bowls seem bigger, more noodles, and tons of toppings.  Surprisingly big chunks of chasu which is nice as Vegas seems to be on the skinnier side when it comes to the meat.  The spicy broth actually delivered a good heat throughout the course, perhaps taking some of the Korean influence from the area with a gochujang-esque accompanied spicy sauce in the bowl.  My filling bowl came to $11 after tax.  In and out in less than 45 minutes. Omoide is a fine option for ramen in the Valley.  But don't overlook the huge menu with tons of rice and noodle options if you're not in the ramen mood.

_CjReRz1bGDenFvuc5SlGg.text: Have been going hear for almost 3 yrs not, I love the spicy miso ramen and the honey toast is the best I have ever had!! Fast and friendly service everytime!

TMFoiFUMy7UpEDIyadiqyQ.text: Great dinner for the value love this place showed it to my friends!  They ordered the cold noodles and I ordered the usual.

MtFt9-Wf4N4QKJTBeUzACg.text: Security and visit and I had the shishito peppers to start. Just the right amount of heat and a nice tangy sauce. I had the chashu don which is a pork belly roll with a mild sweet sauce served over rice. It includes a miso soup, side salad, and some pickles. It was all really good. The atmosphere is so comfortable and the staff has always been so friendly and attentive. Definitely coming back again.

OS5OyjkYywakNAKHsDrrSA.text: Was having a New Year's Eve dinner with family. Placed my order first and got it last. I ordered the Beef Steak Don and it states the meat used is short ribs. When it finally came out after everyone was almost done with their meals, the meat wasn't even short ribs. I told the server that I ordered the short ribs and he said that they don't have short ribs. We asked to see the menu to see where the mistake was and right under the Beef Steak Don it says Beef Short Rib. He asked if we wanted to switch it out for something else and I end up ordering Tempura bowl. 5 mins later he comes back with another disappointment.. they just dumped and cleaned the fryer. It's safe to say I will not be back and will not recommend!
